The problem you describe is, unfortunately, a very simple one. The answers are reasonably obvious, assuming you want answers. Your colleague is right, however, building a coalition requires people willing to join while not seeking unreasonable changes to the basic agreement. Everyone who says "I rather attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act than deal with the jobs problem" is not going to join any group attempting to address jobs. The issue continually comes back to one thing...McConnell's original statement about making the President a one-term President. They failed, but that remains their Prime Directive: Thou shalt not do anything that can be construed as a "win" for the President.

That directive precludes doing anything that remotely improves the lot of the American People. It really is that simple.

Dr. K,

Jared Bernstein report was very gloomy. The level of unemployment in many of the European Union's member states is a cultural catastrophe. My feelings are that the high levels of unemployment in Europe will stretch our own slow recovery & will probably remain a headwind to US growth for many years to come. This is not a problem of economists. Scholars who carry that title rarely discuss the ineptness of their political leaders. Of course, you well know the frustration of the lack of a policy solution to our own high levels of un-and-underemployment.

A Democratic colleague of mine writes, "Democratic leadership in Congress must get back to coalition building by offering new ideas and legislation that proactively create jobs where they are needed the most. Nearly nine million jobs were lost from 2008-2010. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, only 42% of the lost jobs from that period have been recovered and the employment to population ratio stands at 58.6%. Since 2010, almost 600,000 public sector jobs have been lost with teachers leading the way. Rebuilding our Nation's infrastructure would address the loss of construction jobs. Think of the revenue that would be created from an additional 1.5 to 2 million more jobs."

So I ask, why not repeal the Sequester? It is Derpy to continue nonsensical solutions. I also can't fathom why we restored the Payroll Tax cut in the middle of this very weak recovery. What's the problem on a livable wage?

"If we wanted to support democracy in Egypt, why have we continued military aid without requiring structural reforms that would subordinate the military to civilian control, to say nothing of continuing it after this coup?"

The problem with your question started with your first word: "If..."

Our main goal with Egypt always has been to ensure that it honors its 1979 peace agreement with Israel.

If that can be accomplished with a democratic government, all the better. I don't doubt the sincerity of our leaders and diplomats who've worked over the years to achieve that goal.

But the recent coup has highlighted an important point: Though it would be nice to accomplish both goals – protect Israel and bring democracy to Egypt – the second goal counts for very little when our government perceives any risk that the first goal won't be achieved.

In the recent election the Muslim Brotherhood scored 51 percent while the Salefist party won 25 percent. 75 percent is an overwhelming majority in support of a fundamentalist Islamic state. America should not interfere in Egyptian internal affairs nor should we in any way aid and support any state whose basic positions are contrary to our values. Terminate all aid immediately

David, as somebody who reads your articles regularly, I find your current report as baffling as some of your other articles, which often mention other journal articles and books as substantive evidence of what is going on around the social world. As someone who has majored in sociology, I find it hard to take it on face value whether what can be said of Taylor's book you summarized, is generally true of our age. Can what Taylor said be really as prescient as it seems, or can it only be said to speak of his society? These are some questions that I would like to put to you:

1. Are you sure that there are some societies that do not have the all-encompassing, required beliefs that are demanded of their adherents, and whether they actually have a kind of 'secular' choice between spiritual, transcendent types?

2. Do you think art and poetry, in all its forms, truly has the ability to mold people in the way it seems to be, despite all the collective achievements of the past but which so many do not have access (or are educated) to?

3. Is the kind of transcendental values or beliefs necessary for collective action? Is it a requirement for action to be taken for things that people really care about, despite their differences?

I do wish you would have provided a more fuller account about what you think about these questions. Knowing some aspect of the book in a kind of summary does not preclude you from obectivity and thus showing where your inclination lies.

The first time I ever voted in a Canadian election I voted for Charles Taylor. In the last Canadian election I voted for a party led by a student of Charles Taylor. I stand aghast at the flattering portrait painted by David Brooks who stands in complete opposition to what Charles Taylor and the late Jack Layton represent and represented.
I cannot understand how Mr Brooks who exists to defend the basest instincts of humanity, greed, selfishness, hubris and ambition can so warmly embrace Professor Taylor who has throughout his life championed overcoming our basest desires.
As much contempt and dislike as I have for David Brooks I have love and respect for Professor Taylor. Maybe I have been wrong about David Brooks all along and rather than attribute what he writes to evil Mr Brooks is simply an articulate ignoramus.
Before dismissing Professor Taylor because of a flattering portrayal by David Brooks understand that Professor Taylor is one of the great minds of our generation and is about as far removed from a right wing philosophy as it is possible to be in a society based on greed and power.

Mr. Luettgen:
I rarely agree with your comments. But this well- written piece illustrates your gift with the written word, and an interpretation that is quite good.

Perhaps the operative concept is that of "separation of Church and State," by which the Church can no longer wield the power of the State:Five centuries ago, the Inquisitions were attempting to assure orthodoxy. Although there are still those who would like the State to enforce religious orthodoxy, they are much less successful.

The concept of "freedom from" religion springs from the idea of "freedom of" religion. The number of deities extant has shrunk from many to one.

Time for the next logical step to happen, and humanity to become its own species.

The causal factors you describe as Taylor's explanation for a falling away from organized religion while retaining a need for a Hogwarts-like connection to the ethereal strike me as applying only to those who read you regularly -- not insignificant, but hardly representative of the wad. Yet, what we've learned is that currents in our social evolution are governed increasingly by the wad, which in turn are increasingly governed by commercial interest and its supporting manipulation.

In 1500 CE, life was stark and tenuous. That strikes me as manifestly sufficient reason for masses of people to tolerate voluntary herding into atomic religious groups that defined community, membership in which was the primary compensation for inadequate food, dreary and arduous labor, powerless lives and early death; and it also promised a better world, sometimes even in the company of complacent virgins.

As we've developed economically, life has become, for large numbers, quite different: they eat better, live longer, work less hard, and have many more distractions to consume time. Small surprise that they'd be less dependent on a formal shaman and framework to define community: they can choose from among numerous communities. Yet, we still die, eventually, so some ethereal thread mitigating that reality is still sought; but it needn't necessarily be based on images of cross and nails.

And that's as much of a response to a book report that I can manage in 1500 characters (including spaces).
